I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on two proposed 
loans to the Lao People’s Democratic Republic (Lao PDR) for the Greater Mekong Subregion 
Nam Ngum 3 Hydropower Project. The report also describes proposed technical assistance 
(TA)  for  Strengthening  Biodiversity  Protection  and  Management  in  the  Nam  Ngum  3 
Hydropower Project, and if the Board approves the proposed loan, I, acting under the authority 
delegated to me by the Board, will approve the TA. 1  
 
2.  It is proposed that the Asian Development Bank (ADB) provide two project loans to the 
Government of the Lao PDR to support the development of the Nam Ngum 3 Hydropower 
Project and associated dedicated transmission facilities in the Lao PDR for exporting electricity 
to Thailand. The government will use the funds for its equity share in the 440-megawatt (MW) 
build–own–operate–transfer Nam Ngum 3 hydropower plant (NN3). The proposed project will 
(i) potentially provide revenue flows to the government in the form of taxes, royalties, and 
dividends currently estimated at $771 million over the 27 year concession period; (ii) increase 
regional cooperation in the Greater Mekong Subregion (GMS); (iii) promote economic growth in 
the Lao PDR through private sector investment, technology transfer, employment generation, 
and local infrastructure development; and (iv) ensure sustainable development in northeast 
Thailand by achieving energy security and reducing greenhouse gas emissions. The Nam 
Ngum 3 Power Company (NN3PC) will sell to the Electricity Generating Authority of Thailand 
(EGAT) on average 2,072 gigawatt-hours (GWh) annually from NN3, which, if generated by the 
Thai power system, would annually create 1 million tons of carbon-dioxide emissions. The 
proposed NN3 would be the second large-scale hydropower plant to receive ADB financing in 
the Lao PDR, following Nam Theun 2, which was approved in 2005. 
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
A.  Rationale 
3.  Hydropower is the major source of electricity in the Lao PDR, providing stable and 
inexpensive  supplies.  Today,  the  Lao  PDR  has  harnessed  2,530 MW  of  its  estimated 
18,000 MW hydropower capacity, or 14%. About 520 MW is consumed within the country; the 
remaining is exported. Present electrification rate is 64%, and the government plans to achieve 
an  electrification  ratio  of  90%  by  2020.  The  government  has  signed  memoranda  of 
understanding  with  Thailand  and  Viet  Nam  to  export  to  each  of  these  countries  up  to 
7 gigawatts and 5 gigawatts respectively. The government has decided to hold minority equity 
stakes in export-oriented projects to enhance the revenues it receives and allow it to ensure that 
any  adverse  social  and  environmental  impacts  of  projects  are  mitigated  effectively  and 
sustainably. However, the government does not have the resources to raise the financing 
required to build these projects on its own, and needs to mobilize financing from the private 
sector through public–private partnership (PPP). The project is located upstream of two existing 
hydropower plants on the Nam Ngum,2 a tributary to the Mekong, and is considered as a PPP in 
view of close cooperation between the government and its private sector partners in the NN3. 
The PPP mechanism for power projects primarily revolve on the build-operate-transfer concept 
with the off-taker entering into long-term power purchase agreements which guarantee cost

recovery power purchase price. The success of the Nam Theun 2 Hydroelectric Project3 in 
attracting  private  financing  has  encouraged  the  development  of  several  other  hydropower 
projects as PPPs. The construction of 750 MW of hydropower capacity is under way as PPPs. 
Including the proposed NN3, 9,500 MW of hydropower capacity is at various stages of pre-
construction development.    
 
4.  Thailand’s electricity is generated mainly by thermal power plants that burn the fossil 
fuels natural gas and lignite, as Thailand has limited hydropower and other renewable energy 
(solar, biomass and wind) sources to meet the demand growth. Installed capacity in Thailand 
was 29,212 MW in 2009, and peak demand for power reached 22,315 MW. The Thailand Power 
Development Plan, 2010, which runs from 2010 to 2030, estimates that the country will need an 
additional 21,564 MW of electricity-generating capacity by 2020 to maintain economic growth. 
The plan envisions sourcing more than 5 GW from neighboring countries. The proposed NN3 is 
one of the hydropower sources from which Thailand intends to import electricity starting in 
January 2017.  
 
5.  ADB’s country strategy and program (CSP),4 2007–2011 for the Lao PDR aligns with the 
government’s Sixth Socioeconomic Development Plan, 2006–2010, which prioritizes developing 
agriculture and natural resources, education, health, and infrastructure. It incorporates the GMS 
strategy  to  foster  connectivity,  promote  large-scale  foreign  direct  investment,  and  create 
regional public goods. The CSP midterm review, 5 2007–2011 for the Lao PDR recognizes the 
importance of developing hydropower for export to generate foreign currency revenues for the 
government  through  royalties,  taxes,  and  dividends  on  its  equity  investment.  The  PPP 
hydropower projects being developed will help to broaden social and economic development by 
expanding  the government’s revenue  base. The  NN3  loan  is  listed  as firm  in the  country 
operations and business plan for 2011. The regional cooperation business plan, 2010–20126 for 
the GMS has four pillars, two of which the project addresses: (i) integrating national markets to 
promote  economic  efficiency  and  private  sector  development,  and  (ii) managing  the 
environment and shared natural resources to help ensure sustainable development and the 
conservation of natural resources. The project will contribute to achieving these objectives by 
providing low-cost and renewable energy to meet rising demand in Thailand, and by contributing 
to the foreign exchange revenues of the Lao PDR, which will provide funds needed to meet its 
poverty-reduction goals. 
 
B.  Impact and Outcome 
6.  The impact will be increased financial resources for the Government of the Lao PDR to 
allocate for socioeconomic development and increased access to environmentally sustainable 
renewable energy in Thailand. The outcome is increased regional cooperation between the Lao 
PDR and Thailand through the trade of clean energy.

C.  Outputs 
7.  The outputs will be (i) the construction of the NN3 and the associated 500 kilovolt 
transmission line in the Lao PDR as a PPP executed in an environmentally sustainable and 
socially inclusive manner; (ii) $700 million in revenues to the government, of which $202 million 
will  be  earmarked  for  poverty  reduction  programs;  and  (iii)  biodiversity  protection  and 
management capacity strengthened at the Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment.

E.  Implementation Arrangements 
13.  LHSE  will  be  the  executing  agency  and  the  NN3PC  implementing  agency.8 The 
government will enter into the concession agreement with the NN3PC, which defines in full the 
responsibilities of the NN3PC. Annex C of the agreement regulates the implementation of social 
and environmental safeguards. The NN3PC and the government will jointly implement Annex C 
according to agreed responsibility sharing described in the project administration manual.  
 
14.  Potential revenue flows to the government are currently estimated at $771 million9 over 
27 years starting in 2017. The commitment is to direct $202 million in dividends to priority 
sectors focusing on poverty reduction and environmental management to ensure that the project 
impact is significant. The proposed revenue management arrangements10 will mirror existing 
arrangements regarding (i) the allocation of revenues to eligible priority programs and (ii) the

Public Financial Management Strengthening Program11, including arrangements to (i) include 
the allocation of revenues as an integral part of budget execution reports filed by the Ministry of 
Finance, and (ii) strengthening audit arrangements under the State Audit Organization with 
regular monitoring using existing institutional arrangements for monitoring and evaluation.

III.  TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
15.  A $530,000 advisory TA will be provided with the loans for Strengthening Biodiversity 
Protection and Management in the Nam Ngum 3 Hydropower Project.12 The TA will be financed 
through the Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-IV) for $500,000. The Government will 
provide $30,000 in kind. ADB will be the executing agency for the TA, and the Ministry of 
Natural Resources and Environment will be the implementing agency. The TA consultants will 
be selected and engaged in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants 
(2010, as amended from time to time). The disbursements will be made in accordance with 
ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2007, as amended from time to time).13 
The TA is expected to commence in November 2011 and finish in December 2017. The TA’s 
impact is mitigation of adverse biodiversity impacts of the project through establishment of 
effective biodiversity protection and offset program. The TA’s outcome is effective integration of 
biodiversity conservation issues in design and implementation of NN3. The proposed TA will 
help Government of Lao PDR effectively assess the project impacts on biodiversity and natural

IV.  DUE DILIGENCE 
A.  Technical 
16.  ADB conducted technical due diligence on the proposed investment and is satisfied with 
the  rationale,  technical  specifications,  quantities,  and  cost  estimates.  The  project  forms  a 
cascade with other projects planned, existing, and under construction in the Nam Ngum Basin.14  
Located about 115 kilometer (km) north of Vientiane on the Nam Ngum, it consists of a 220 
meter high concrete-faced rockfill dam, a 10.6 km tunnel, an underground power station with an 
installed capacity of 440 MW, and nearly 1 km tailrace tunnel conveying the water back to the 
Nam Ngum. The distance from the power house to the confluence with the Mekong is about 256 
km, of which 72 km is occupied by the Nam Ngum 1 and Nam Ngum 2 reservoirs, both totaling 
572 square kilometers of surface area at full supply level, located between the project and the 
Mekong. The estimated mean annual energy generation of 2,114 GWh will be evacuated via a 
99 km, 500 kilovolts double-circuit transmission line to the planned Nabong substation,15 from 
where it will be delivered to EGAT on the Lao PDR–Thailand border.16 The dam will create a 
long and narrow reservoir with a surface area of 27.5 square kilometers. The dam will be one of 
the highest of its type in the world, and the highest in the Lao PDR. The technology of concrete-
faced rockfill dams is well understood. However, it has been decided to establish a Dam Safety 
Review Panel to ensure the safety of the project during construction and operation stages. The 
technology of the chosen Francis turbines is also mature and will operate within well-known 
limits.17

C.  Governance 
19.  Financial consultants prepared a financial management assessment of LHSE, including 
a risk management assessment, in accordance with ADB guidelines. As a holding company for 
government investments, LHSE does not directly construct, own, or operate the projects it 
invests in. Instead, it purchases equity in the special purpose company established for each 
project. LHSE has no direct role in project procurement or related disbursements. GMS Lao, the 
main proponent in NN3PC, has ample experience in procurement using internationally accepted 
processes. Further, procurement undertaken so far for the project, which includes the three 
main contract packages, was monitored by the Lender’s Technical Adviser and found to be 
acceptable by ADB. 
 
20.  LHSE has previous experience with ADB and other development partners through its 
purchase of equity in the Nam Theun 2 Power Company, which was funded with the proceeds 
of grants and loans from ADB, the World Bank’s International Development Association, the 
European Investment Bank, and Agence Française de Développement. Project implementation 
was undertaken by the Nam Theun 2 Power Company, the project owner. LHSE’s functions and 
responsibilities were limited to disbursing loan proceeds used to fund its equity purchase in the 
project.  ADB  assessed  LHSE’s  performance  as  satisfactory.  As  a  shareholder  in  project 
companies, LHSE has financial management systems generally sufficient to record, monitor, 
control, and report on project-related financial transactions. 
 
21.  ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with the government and LHSE. The specific policy requirements and supplementary measures 
are described in the project administration manual. 
 
D.  Poverty and Social 
22.  Poverty in the Lao PDR has strong correlations with geography and ethnic identity. 
While poverty has declined nationally, 58% of households in northern provinces are poor, 
compared with 4.4% in Vientiane Capital. This is partly because of mountainous terrain and 
access difficulties, and partly because a higher proportion of ethnic minorities in these areas. 
Poverty incidence among ethnic minorities in the Lao PDR is 40%–55%, greater than in the 
majority Lao PDR-Thailand rate of 29%. Almost all affected people in the project impact area 
are  ethnic  minorities,  whose  subsistence  livelihoods  depend  heavily  on  natural  resources. 
Directly  and  indirectly  affected  communities  will  benefit  from  improved  access  to  markets, 
secondary  education,  health-care  facilities,  with  the  provision  of  all-weather  roads,  and 
electricity. Xaysomboun District’s economy will be significantly affected, by net benefits in the 
form of accelerated economic growth, reduced poverty, and new jobs. Currently limited health-
care infrastructure and services in affected areas will be upgraded with improved year-round

9 
access and services. Also, resettled households will be assured of permanent tenure rights to 
housing and agricultural land, to protect their continued access to natural resources, which will 
be a first in rural areas of Phoukout District. Details of resettlement and restoration management 
processes are in the resettlement and ethnic minority development plan. 
23.  The influx of labor and camp followers will apply pressure on existing sanitation and 
public  health  facilities,  while  increasing  the  risk  of  sexual  exploitation  of  women  and  the 
associated risk of HIV transmission. Ethnic minority women and children are typically more 
vulnerable to exploitation. The project has developed several plans described in the EIA to 
mitigate these issues.  
 
E.  Safeguards 
24.  The project is classified category A18 for environment, for involuntary resettlement, and 
for indigenous people under the SPS. The potential environment and social impacts and risks of 
the Project and its associated facilities were identified and assessed in the Environmental 
Impact  Assessment  which  has  been  posed  on  ADB's  website  since  14  January  2011.  A 
cumulative impact assessment for the Project was completed in 2007.19 A peer review was 
conducted on 11 February 2011; review of its later versions were undertaken to enhance 
mitigation measures and conservation and offset programs to meet SPS requirements.  NN3PC 
will undertake an updated comprehensive biodiversity study on project areas commencing in the 
last  quarter  of  2011  to  reconfirm  the  extent  of  conservation  and  offset  programs.  An 
Independent  Advisory  Panel,  to  be  financed  by  ADB,  will  be  constituted  to  assist  the 
government  evaluate  the  impacts  on  biodiversity,  assess  the  adequacy  of  recommended 
measures to achieve a no net loss of biodiversity and implement an effective biodiversity offset 
programs. Measures to address the social impacts of the project are described in the draft 
Resettlement and Ethnic Minority Development Plan which has been posted on ADB’s website 
on 6 June 2011. The directly affected Khmu ethnic community living in Ban Xiengdet has 
provided broad community support to the Project. Such support is documented in meeting 
agreements and household level consent to relocate forms authenticated by village leaders. 
Effective measures to avoid, minimize, mitigate and compensate for the adverse impacts, and to 
ensure compliance with ADB’s social protection requirements, are incorporated in the safeguard 
reports and plans. The institutional capacity and commitment of NN3PC to manage project’s 
environmental and social risks are deemed adequate,20 while collaboration with the NNRBC is 
considered  crucial  in  managing  cumulative  impacts  at  the  river  basin  level.  Information 
disclosure  and  consultations  have  been  and  will  be  conducted  in  accordance  with  ADB 
requirements. 
 
F.  Risks and Mitigating Measures 
25.  Major risks and mitigating measures are described in detail in the risk assessment and 
risk management plan.21 The project benefits are expected to outweigh the mitigated risks.

Assessment for the Nam Ngum 3 Hydropower Project. Manila. 
20  Both the Environmental and Social Safeguards Summary and the Summary Poverty Reduction and Social Strategy 
are accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2.

10 
V.  ASSURANCES AND CONDITIONS 
26.  The government and LHSE have assured ADB that implementation of the project shall 
conform to all applicable ADB policies including those concerning anticorruption measures, 
safeguards, gender, procurement, consulting services, and disbursement as described in detail 
in the project administration manual and loan documents. 
 
27.  The government and LHSE have agreed with ADB on certain covenants for the project, 
which are set forth in the loan agreement and project agreement. 
 
28.  The effectiveness of the loans are conditional upon (i) the subsidiary loan agreement on 
behalf of the Government and LHSE becoming effective, and (ii) the concession agreement, 
acceptable to ADB becoming effective.  
29.  Each request by the borrower for a withdrawal from the loan account for a deposit of 
funds into a designated NN3PC account shall be accompanied with (i) a certification that goods 
and works have been obtained from an ADB member country (ii) an interim payment certificate; 
and (iii) the endorsement of the interim payment certificate by the lender’s technical advisors. 
Such documents shall be provided by NN3PC through LHSE for eligible costs for the month 
following the date of such request is submitted to MOF. 
 
VI.  RECOMMENDATION 
30.  I am satisfied that the proposed loans would comply with the Articles of Agreement of 
the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve  
 
(i)  the loan of $98,200,000 to the Lao People’s Democratic Republic for the Greater 
Mekong Subregion Nam Ngum 3 Hydropower Project from ADB’s ordinary capital 
resources,  with  interest  to  be  determined  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  London 
interbank  offered  rate  (LIBOR)-based  lending  facility;  for  a  term  of  25  years, 
including a grace period of 7 years; and such other terms and conditions as are 
substantially  in  accordance  with  those  set  forth  in  the  draft  loan  and  project 
agreements presented to the Board; and  
(ii)  the loan in various currencies equivalent to SDR10,619,000 to the Lao People’s 
Democratic Republic for the Greater Mekong Subregion Nam Ngum 3 Hydropower 
Project from ADB’s Special Funds resources with an interest charge at the rate of 
2.02% per annum; for a term of 32 years, including a grace period of 8 years; and 
such other terms and conditions as are substantially in accordance with those set 
forth in the draft loan and project agreements presented to the Board. 
 
 
Haruhiko Kuroda 
President
